a: Dharma means righteousness and duty.
Hinduism, also known as Sanatana Dharma, is the oldest living religion in the world. It is a diverse spiritual tradition that includes philosophies, rituals, devotion, yoga, and meditation.
Sanatana Dharma means the eternal duty or eternal law. It refers to timeless spiritual truths that govern the universe and human life.
Dharma means righteousness, duty, moral order, and the correct way of living according to cosmic law.
Karma is the universal law of cause and effect. Every action, thought, and intention produces consequences in this life or future lives.
Samsara is the endless cycle of birth, death, and rebirth governed by karma.
Moksha is liberation from Samsara. It is the ultimate goal of life where the soul realizes its true nature and becomes free from rebirth.
Atman is the true self or soul. It is eternal, pure consciousness, and distinct from the physical body and mind.
Brahman is the ultimate, infinite, formless reality that is the source of all existence.
Advaita Vedanta is a philosophy that teaches non-duality, stating that Atman and Brahman are one and the same.
Adi Shankaracharya was an 8th-century philosopher who consolidated the philosophy of Advaita Vedanta.
Brahma is the creator god in Hinduism and part of the Trimurti.
Vishnu is the preserver of the universe and protector of Dharma. He incarnates as avatars to restore cosmic balance.
Shiva is the destroyer and transformer. He represents meditation, renunciation, and cosmic consciousness.
The Trimurti consists of Brahma the Creator, Vishnu the Preserver, and Shiva the Destroyer.
Krishna is the eighth avatar of Vishnu and the speaker of the Bhagavad Gita. He represents divine love and wisdom.
Rama is the seventh avatar of Vishnu and the hero of the Ramayana, symbolizing ideal conduct and righteousness.
Lakshmi is the goddess of wealth, prosperity, and fortune, and the consort of Vishnu.
Saraswati is the goddess of knowledge, wisdom, music, and learning.
Durga is the divine mother who protects the universe and destroys evil forces.
Ganesha is the remover of obstacles and the god of wisdom, intellect, and new beginnings.
Hanuman is a symbol of strength, devotion, and selfless service, and a devotee of Lord Rama.
The Ramayana is an epic that narrates the life of Lord Rama and his victory over Ravana.
The Mahabharata is a great epic that describes the Kurukshetra war and contains the Bhagavad Gita.
The Bhagavad Gita is a sacred dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna that teaches duty, devotion, and liberation.
The Vedas are the oldest sacred scriptures of Hinduism, consisting of Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvaveda.
The Upanishads are philosophical texts that explore the nature of reality, Atman, and Brahman.
Yoga is a spiritual discipline that unites body, mind, and soul through practice and meditation.
Bhakti Yoga is the path of devotion and love toward God.
Karma Yoga is the path of selfless action performed without attachment to results.
Jnana Yoga is the path of knowledge and self-inquiry.
Raja Yoga is the path of meditation and control of the mind.
Maya is the cosmic illusion that causes beings to perceive the temporary world as ultimate reality.
Ahimsa is the principle of non-violence in thought, word, and action.
Puja is a ritual of worship performed to honor and communicate with the divine.
Prasad is food offered to a deity and then shared as a blessing.
A Guru is a spiritual teacher who guides a disciple toward self-realization.
A Mantra is a sacred sound or phrase chanted for spiritual transformation.
Om is the primordial sound symbolizing the ultimate reality.
Yajna is a sacred fire ritual performed with offerings and mantras.
A Hindu temple is a sacred space designed to connect humans with the divine.
A Sannyasi is one who renounces worldly life in pursuit of liberation.
The Varna system categorizes society based on duties: Brahmin, Kshatriya, Vaishya, and Shudra.
Diwali is the festival of lights symbolizing victory of light over darkness.
Holi is the festival of colors celebrating joy and the triumph of good over evil.
Navaratri is a nine-night festival honoring the divine feminine.
Raksha Bandhan celebrates the bond between brothers and sisters.
Yama is the god of death and justice who judges souls after death.
The Swastika is an ancient symbol of auspiciousness and well-being in Hinduism.
The Purusharthas are the four goals of human life in Hinduism: Dharma (duty), Artha (prosperity), Kama (pleasure), and Moksha (liberation).
Artha refers to the pursuit of material wealth, prosperity, and financial security necessary for a dignified life.
Kama refers to desire, pleasure, love, and emotional fulfillment within the boundaries of Dharma.
The three Gunas are qualities of nature: Sattva (purity/harmony), Rajas (activity/passion), and Tamas (inertia/darkness).
Sattva is the quality of balance, harmony, purity, and intelligence.
Rajas is the quality of energy, movement, ambition, and passion.
Tamas is the quality of lethargy, darkness, ignorance, and inertia.
The Srimad Bhagavatam (Bhagavata Purana) is a revered text focused on deep devotion (Bhakti) to Lord Vishnu, particularly his incarnation as Krishna.
Vedavyasa is the sage traditionally credited with classifying the Vedas and writing the Mahabharata and Puranas.
Mantra Diksha is the initiation ceremony where a Guru gives a specific sacred mantra to a disciple.
The Gayatri Mantra is a highly revered Vedic mantra addressed to Savitr (the Sun deity), praying for illumination of the intellect.
Kartikeya (also known as Murugan or Skanda) is the god of war, the son of Shiva and Parvati, and the commander of the divine army.
Kali is a fierce form of the Divine Mother who destroys ego and illusions to liberate the soul.
Mahashivaratri is the 'Great Night of Shiva,' a festival celebrated with fasting and meditation to honor Lord Shiva.
Janmashtami is the festival celebrating the birth of Lord Krishna.
Rama Navami celebrates the birth of Lord Rama.
Ganesh Chaturthi is a festival celebrating the arrival of Lord Ganesha, often involving the installation of clay idols.
Kumbh Mela is a massive pilgrimage and festival where millions gather to bathe in sacred rivers to wash away sins.
The Char Dham are four sacred pilgrimage sites in India: Badrinath, Dwarka, Puri, and Rameswaram.
Varanasi is one of the oldest living cities and a major spiritual center dedicated to Lord Shiva, believed to grant liberation.
Rudraksha beads are seeds from the Elaeocarpus ganitrus tree, considered sacred to Lord Shiva and used for prayer beads (mala).
A Mala is a string of beads (usually 108) used for counting mantras during meditation.
Aarti is a ritual of worship in which light (usually from a flame) is offered to a deity to express devotion.
A Bhajan is a devotional song with religious themes or spiritual ideas.
Kirtan is a call-and-response chanting session of mantras or divine names.
Vedanta refers to the philosophy based on the Upanishads, occurring at the 'end of the Vedas'.
Dvaita Vedanta is the philosophy of dualism founded by Madhvacharya, stating that God and the individual soul are eternally distinct.
Vishishtadvaita is the philosophy of qualified non-dualism founded by Ramanuja, stating that souls are part of God but retain individuality.
Swami Vivekananda was a 19th-century monk who introduced Vedanta and Yoga to the West and emphasized service to humanity.
Sri Ramakrishna was a 19th-century mystic who experienced the unity of all religions through intense devotion.

q: What is the significance of the Lotus in Hinduism?
a: The Lotus symbolizes purity, detachment, and spiritual enlightenment, as it grows in mud but remains unstained.
A Tilak is a mark worn on the forehead to denote sect affiliation or spiritual focus, usually made of sandalwood paste, ash, or kumkum.
Vibhuti is sacred ash applied to the body, symbolizing the transient nature of life and purity.
Kumkum is a red powder used for social and religious markings, often associated with the goddess Lakshmi.
Prana is the vital life force or energy that flows through the body and universe.
Chakras are energy centers within the subtle body, with seven main ones aligned along the spine.
Kundalini is the dormant spiritual energy coiled at the base of the spine, which can be awakened through Yoga.
Ayurveda is the ancient Indian system of medicine focusing on balancing bodily humors (Doshas) for health.
The three Doshas in Ayurveda are Vata (air/ether), Pitta (fire/water), and Kapha (earth/water).
Dhanteras marks the first day of Diwali festivities, dedicated to wealth and the god of medicine, Dhanvantari.
Dhanvantari is the physician of the gods and the avatar of Vishnu who brought Ayurveda to mankind.
Makar Sankranti is a harvest festival marking the transition of the sun into the zodiac sign of Capricorn.
Ishta Devata is a devotee's chosen deity, the specific form of God they feel the closest connection to.
Shraaddha is a ritual performed to pay respects to ancestors and ensure their peace.
Pitru Paksha is a 16-day lunar period when Hindus pay homage to their ancestors.
Gotra refers to a lineage or clan assigned to a Hindu at birth, tracing descent from an ancient sage.
Swayamvara was an ancient practice where a woman chose her husband from a group of suitors.
The Pandavas are the five brothers (Yudhishthira, Bhima, Arjuna, Nakula, Sahadeva) who are the protagonists of the Mahabharata.
The Kauravas were the 100 brothers, led by Duryodhana, who fought against the Pandavas in the Mahabharata.
Draupadi is the wife of the five Pandavas and a central figure in the Mahabharata.
Akshaya Tritiya is an auspicious day believed to bring never-ending success and prosperity.
Satya Yuga is the first and best of the four ages (Yugas), characterized by truth and righteousness.
Treta Yuga is the second age, where virtue declines slightly; it is the era of Lord Rama.
Dvapara Yuga is the third age, the era of Lord Krishna.
Kali Yuga is the current age, characterized by conflict, ignorance, and a decline in spiritual values.
Kalki is the prophesied tenth avatar of Vishnu who will appear at the end of Kali Yuga to restore Dharma.
A Kalasha is a metal pot topped with coconut and mango leaves, used in rituals to represent the deity or abundance.
Namaste is a traditional greeting meaning 'I bow to the divine in you'.
A Bindi is a decorative mark worn in the middle of the forehead, traditionally symbolizing the third eye.
Mundan is the ritual of the first haircut for a child, symbolizing the shedding of past life traits.
Vivaha is the Hindu wedding ceremony, considered a sacred sacrament (Samskara).
Saptapadi (Seven Steps) is the most important rite in a Hindu wedding, where the couple takes seven vows around the fire.
Sindoor is vermilion powder applied by married women along the parting of their hair.
The Mangalsutra is a sacred necklace tied by the groom around the bride's neck symbolizing marriage.
Antyesti is the funeral rite or 'last sacrifice' in Hinduism, typically involving cremation.

q: What is the difference between Shruti and Smriti?
a: Shruti ('that which is heard') refers to revealed scriptures like Vedas; Smriti ('that which is remembered') refers to traditional texts like Puranas and Epics.

q: What are the six systems of Indian Philosophy (Darshanas)?
a: The six orthodox systems are Nyaya, Vaisheshika, Samkhya, Yoga, Mimamsa, and Vedanta.
Samkhya is a dualistic philosophy that describes the universe as an interaction between Purusha (consciousness) and Prakriti (matter).
Patanjali is the sage who compiled the Yoga Sutras, the foundational text of Raja Yoga.
The Yamas are ethical restraints in Yoga: Ahimsa (non-violence), Satya (truthfulness), Asteya (non-stealing), Brahmacharya (continence), and Aparigraha (non-possessiveness).
The Niyamas are observances in Yoga: Saucha (purity), Santosha (contentment), Tapas (discipline), Svadhyaya (self-study), and Ishvara Pranidhana (surrender to God).
Tulsidas was a saint-poet best known for writing the Ramcharitmanas, a retelling of the Ramayana in Awadhi.
Hanuman Chalisa is a 40-verse devotional hymn in praise of Lord Hanuman, written by Tulsidas.
Mirabai was a 16th-century saint and poet devoted to Lord Krishna.
Kabir was a mystic poet whose writings influenced Hinduism's Bhakti movement, emphasizing the formless God.
Vaishnavism is a major sect of Hinduism that reveres Vishnu and his avatars as the Supreme God.
Shaivism is a major sect of Hinduism that reveres Shiva as the Supreme Being.
Shaktism is a major sect of Hinduism that worships the Goddess (Devi) as the Supreme Power.
Smartism is a tradition that follows the domestic rituals and worships five deities (Ganesha, Shiva, Shakti, Vishnu, Surya) equally.
A Yantra is a geometrical diagram used in meditation and rituals to represent specific deities or cosmic energies.
The Sri Yantra is a complex sacred geometry representing the goddess Lakshmi and the union of masculine and feminine divine.
Satsang means 'association with truth', referring to a gathering of spiritual seekers to listen to teachings or chant.
Seva means selfless service performed without expectation of reward, often as an offering to God.
Vairagya means dispassion or detachment from worldly desires.
Vivek is discernment, the ability to distinguish between the real (eternal) and the unreal (temporary).
Hatha Yoga is a branch of Yoga focusing on physical postures (asanas) and breath control (pranayama) to prepare the body for meditation.
Pranayama is the practice of breath control used to regulate the flow of Prana (life energy).
Asana refers to physical postures practiced in Yoga.
Dhyana means meditation or sustained concentration.
Samadhi is the state of intense concentration or absorption where the meditator merges with the object of meditation.
Ayyappa is a deity popular in South India, believed to be the son of Shiva and Mohini (female avatar of Vishnu), known for the Sabarimala pilgrimage.
Jagannath ('Lord of the Universe') is a form of Krishna worshipped primarily in Puri, Odisha.
Ratha Yatra is the chariot festival of Lord Jagannath in Puri.
Chhath Puja is a festival dedicated to the Sun God (Surya) and his consort Usha, involving fasting and standing in water.
Vasant Panchami marks the arrival of spring and is dedicated to worshiping Goddess Saraswati.
Guru Purnima is a festival dedicated to spiritual and academic teachers, celebrated on the full moon day.
Dakshina is a donation or fee given to a priest or Guru as a sign of respect and gratitude.
Brahmacharya is a mode of behavior, often translated as celibacy or student life, focused on self-restraint and study of Vedas.
Grihastha is the householder stage of life, focused on family, work, and social duties.
Vanaprastha is the retired stage of life, where one gradually withdraws from worldly duties.
